title: I need to get a prenup in California. Do I need to have to separate lawyers? One for me and one for my fiancé? What's the cost?
question: My fiancé is from Sweden and is in $41,000 dollars of student loan debt that I don't want to be responsible for. Also, do I need to get a prenup or will a postnup work? What's the difference? Thanks for the help.
answers:
A prenuptial agreement is made in contemplation of marriage. A postnuptial agreement is entered into by 2 spouses after marriage. If done in compliance with the CA Family Code, prenuptial agreements are presumptively valid.. On the other hand, if one party obtains an "unfair advantage" under a postnuptial agreement, then there is a presumption against the enforceability of the agreement. This does not mean that the postnuptial agreement will not be enforced, but it shifts the burden of proof.

Whether you choose a prenuptial or postnuptial agreement, you both should have your own independent attorneys who should sign off on the agreement. Also, it would be beneficial to have the final version of the agreement translated into Swedish by a professional translation service.

Community property is liable for the premarital debts of the parties, except for earnings that are kept separate. The separate property of one spouse is not liable for the premarital debts of the other spouse. Money you put in a joint checking account after marriage is going to be community property, and can be reached by your fiance's creditors after your marriage. Therefore the solution to your problem is to prevent community property from arising in your marriage. In general, you can do that in a prenup which provides that all your earnings during the marriage are your separate property, and that any business you may own when you marry will remain your separate property. I'd advise you to do a prenup rather than a postnup, whose validity might be questioned as a fraudulent conveyance. As my colleagues have suggested, getting a bulletproof prenup is difficult because of relatively new statutory requirements. You need a lawyer, and you need her to have a lawyer - an independent one - as well. Spousal support can be waived in a prenup, but not in a postnup. Costs vary.

Postnups are highly disfavored. Pre nuptial agreements take care of issues before marriage. They must be done very carefully with an eye to full disclosure of all assets and debts by the parties and an opportunity for each party to seek separate advice from an attorney if they so desire as to the terms of the agreement. As to costs, that also depends on the complexity of the agreement. Each attorney will give different estimates of costs. Suggest you start the process of interviewing potential attorneys.

I concur with my colleagues, and I think most people should have a prenup. That said, her student debt would not become a community debt.

Post nups are not so great, for several reasons. Do this now.

In order to prevent her from later raising the issue of undue influence, you each need to have separate lawyers review the prenuptial agreement. You can always enter into a post-nuptial agreement (transmutation), however, there is a presumption that whatever is acquired during the marriage in CP and if she refuses to sign you will be out of luck.

The short answer is yes, you both need lawyers if you want it to be enforceable. You use a pre-nup before marriage and a post-nup after you are married if you don't have a pre-nup.

The facts of your case are similar to Marriage of Bonds (2000) (That's Barry- the baseball player). His wife was from Sweden. In that case the Supreme Court upheld the pre-nup but the code was changed the next year to prevent that result. I'd also consider some type of interpreter with a declaration so your fiancee can understand what she is signing.
